Jo, You stated that you think homophobes use religion as a fig leaf to cover their beliefs. If this were true wouldn't you expect a more even distribution of homophobic incidents occuring between people of religious and non-religious background?

Not sure what you're saying, are you saying that religious or non-religious people are likely to be responsible to homophobic incidents?
 
 I've seen more than a few instances of religion being used as a cover for homophobia, the BNP are notorious for using the Lord's Prayer at rallies to try and cover their hate with a veneer of Christianity. I think in other cases genuine believers with a weakness for hating others find a convenient outlet in gay people.

Whilst your thoughts have a ring of truth about them the figures that were posted by one member (Iangb/Penfold?) from the Gay Police assoc. stating that the majority of violent homophobic incidents were related to the perpetrators religious beliefs would appear to contradict the hypothesis.
 If only 7% of the population are church-goers you might expect a similar proportion of incidents if homophobia is not related to religion, (assuming church-goers have the stronger beliefs, access to scripture/publications, subject to possibly homophobic sermons etc.) One thing that does occur to me is a possible ethnic discrepancy in the incidents as the Afro-Carribean community are noted as having strong views on the subject.

But how is motivation by religious belief defined? Is that simply the justification given to police? I think it would also vary depending on the sort of incident. Organised homophobia, harrassment of pride marches etc. I agree is more likely to be through religious organisations, but I suspect that low level "casual" homophobia that won't get reported to the police is likely to come from a broader swathe of the population. There is also the fact that the idea of separation and difference, and a feeling of superiority over others, can be part of the attraction of fundamentalist forms of Christianity, and hence they attract people who are already pre-disposed to homophobia.

I think this is what the other poster was refering to, if so it is slightly out of date.

 It gives some description of what it terms an "incident".
 
Verbal abuse and physical assault against gay men and women is a criminal offence and should always be reported to the police. Discrimination against gay people in the workplace is also unlawful and should be reported to employers, who have a duty of care to prevent it. Homophobia can never be justified and must never be tolerated.
